text:
Second Avenue, north from East Houston Street, showing this main East Side thoroughfare at its inception.

July 1928.

Geo. L. Balgue,

(1)

252-256 East Houston Street, north side, between Avenue A and B, as seen from Norfolk Street.  May 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, showing a further view east to and including No. 264 East Houston Street. 262 and 264 are 4-story frame houses with brick fronts.

April 8, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

252-256 East Houston Street, north side, between Avenue A and B, as seen from Norfolk Street.  May 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, showing a further view east to and including No. 264 East Houston Street. 262 and 264 are 4-story frame houses with brick fronts.

April 8, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

N.W. corner of Second Avenue and East Houston Street.
July 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(1)

East Houston Street, west from but not including the Bowery, as seen from the Fisher Building (No. 97-103 East Houston Street, between the Bowery and Chrystie Street). Also shown is a general view of the surrounding area. The buildings on the north side of the street, to the depth of 10 feet were razed to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). The buildings in the foreground, of which only the upper stories are visible are on the west side of the Bowery.

July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A portion of the view shown in No. 1 (north side) at a later date, as seen from the Houston Street Station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line, on the Bowery, and showing an exclusive view of Houston Street. Note the clearance between Elizabeth and Mott Streets after the houses which occupied that site were razed. The other buildings were demolished later.

September 19, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

A portion of the view shown in No. 1. Also shown (right) are Nos. 286 to 310 Bowery, west side, north from East Houston, to but not including Bleecker Street. In the foreground appears a portion of the Houston Street station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.

P. L. Sperr.

July 17, 1929.

(1)

East Houston Street, west from but not including the Bowery, as seen from the Fisher Building (No. 97-103 East Houston Street, between the Bowery and Chrystie Street). Also shown is a general view of the surrounding area. The buildings on the north side of the street, to the depth of 10 feet were razed to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). The buildings in the foreground, of which only the upper stories are visible are on the west side of the Bowery.

July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A portion of the view shown in No. 1 (north side) at a later date, as seen from the Houston Street Station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line, on the Bowery, and showing an exclusive view of Houston Street. Note the clearance between Elizabeth and Mott Streets after the houses which occupied that site were razed. The other buildings were demolished later.

September 19, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

A portion of the view shown in No. 1. Also shown (right) are Nos. 286 to 310 Bowery, west side, north from East Houston, to but not including Bleecker Street. In the foreground appears a portion of the Houston Street station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.

P. L. Sperr.

July 17, 1929.

(1)

East Houston Street, west from but not including the Bowery, as seen from the Fisher Building (No. 97-103 East Houston Street, between the Bowery and Chrystie Street). Also shown is a general view of the surrounding area. The buildings on the north side of the street, to the depth of 10 feet were razed to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). The buildings in the foreground, of which only the upper stories are visible are on the west side of the Bowery.

July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A portion of the view shown in No. 1 (north side) at a later date, as seen from the Houston Street Station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line, on the Bowery, and showing an exclusive view of Houston Street. Note the clearance between Elizabeth and Mott Streets after the houses which occupied that site were razed. The other buildings were demolished later.

September 19, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

A portion of the view shown in No. 1. Also shown (right) are Nos. 286 to 310 Bowery, west side, north from East Houston, to but not including Bleecker Street. In the foreground appears a portion of the Houston Street station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.

P. L. Sperr.

July 17, 1929.

120-122 (left), and 124-126 East Houston Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Second Ave., showing the store-fronts of two 5-story buildings. The entire block of houses of which these are a part were later demolished to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). On their site is now (1937) a playground and park.

P. L. Sperr.

July 17, 1929.

128 East Houston Street, east of the N.E. corner of Second Ave., showing the store-front of a 6-story tenement house. This building, together with the others comprising the block between Second and First Aves., were later razed to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway). July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

138 to 142 (left to right) East Houston Street, north side, east of Second Ave., as seen when viewed northward on Forsyth Street. The entire block of houses of which these were a part, were demolished to facilitate the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. Subway). The site is now a public playground. On the extreme left appears buildings at the S.W. corner of East Houston and Forsyth Streets, which today (1937) are gone; the same being a portion of the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Park.

July 13, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

East Houston Street, east from but not including the Bowery, showing construction work in progress (on the north side of the street), on the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway), after the buildings which previously had occupied that area, were razed. In the background is visible a portion of the Second Ave. Elevated Line, running at this point on First Ave.

October 12, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

East Houston Street, north side, east from but not including Second Ave., showing construction work on the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. Subway) after the houses which stood on this site were razed. This area was later transformed into a playground. On the extreme left are seen the rears of buildings facing on East 1st Street, between Second and First Aves. Also shown (background) is the 1st Street station of the Second Ave. Elevated Line, running at this point on First Ave.

May 9, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Recreation--billiards: The entrance to a pocket billiards place on Second Avenue near E. Houston Street, Manhattan. Note the warning on the doorway: "No Minors Allowed; No Drunks Allowed!"

Committee on Housing
Charity Organization Society

1930's
title: Recreation - Billiards.

text:
9 Second Avenue, between Houston and 1st Streets, west side: "Germain a Flats". Church of All Nations is in first floor right.
January 16, 1931.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

East Houston Street, at the N.E. corner of the Bowery, showing the clearance created by the demolition of the houses which occupied that site. The buildings shown (plus a 1, and 5-story annexes) are facing on the Bowery. Also shown (extreme left) is a portion of the Third Ave. Elevated line on the Bowery. This area between Second and Third Aves. is today (1937) an automobile parking lot.
March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

East Houston Street, north side, at the foot of Second Ave. (where bus is parked), as seen from the foot of Forsyth Street, looking north-westward. The clearance shown was created as a result of the demolition of houses which formerly stood there, to make way for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway).
March 13, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

East Houston Street, at the N.E. corner of Second Ave., and showing the rears of buildings on the south side of East 1st Street, across clearance occasioned by the new Eighth Ave. Subway link.

October 28, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

Manhattan

Advertisements - Signs
East Houston St. and 2nd Ave.
Feb. 11, 1937

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Photographs by Berenice Abbott
title: Advertisements - Signs.
